title: Why do stars look very near to us? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you have the possibility to use a telescope and look at the sky, you’re going to see something like this: we know that the moon and the planets are near, so when we look at them we see them magnified, we see details of the surface and we can distinguish features like craters on the moon or the atmospheric stripes on Jupiter.But if you look at the stars, no matter how powerful your telescope is, you will always see a point. This means that they are emitting a looot of energy such that you can see them, but they are sooo far away that you will never be able to “see” the surface or distinguish feature on it (like we do on the Sun, where we can see sunspots for example).

If SPIRAL cosmological model we see them from a max distance when they were a lot closer than if the current consensus LCDM-SCM.Thousands vs Billions of LY.
